issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.
status.name: Patch Available

fields.description:
Looking at {{BlockStoragePolicySuite.getPolicy(name)}}, is using {{equalsIgnoreCase()}} to find a policy which matches a name.

This will not work in all locales. It must use {{toLowerCase(Locale.ENGLISH).equals(name)}}
fields.summary: BlockStoragePolicySuite uses equalsIgnoreCase for name lookup, won't work in all locales

comments.body: I should add that the locale most likely to break is turkey, where {{"I".toLowerCase()!="i"}}, so matches the policy {{"lazy_persist"}} wont match {{"LAZY_PERSIST"}}
[~stevel@apache.org] Attached the patch.. Kindly Review.. thanks

This message was automatically generated.
if it's not doing the case conversion, then that's a critical defect. Yes, fix it

we can't guarantee that holds across all JDK versions, it crops up intermittently : https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8041791

that's why I'd like to to be used with the case conversions: consistency.

the alternative is to leave as is and convert those demos to tests -but that won't catch the recurrent problem of the JDK used for release testing not being the same as people use in production (especially over time).

We now have one place for the operation: let's switch to it. Maybe add in the javadocs a link to this JIRA and some explanation of reasoning, "we can't trust JDKs"

[~steve_l], I believe the JDK bugs you mentioned are for non-English letters.  For English letters, it seems that equalIgoreCase always works well.  We never uses non-English letters in our code.  So we are safe.  No?
